title: What's the best method for singing with your diaphragm? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi Sarah, and thanks for the A2A. I’m going to keep this simple. So in terms of physiology, the diaphragm is a muscle used for inhalation, so I’m not sure the expression “sing with your diaphragm” is literally accurate. Here’s what I have been taught though. First, find and maintain good body alignment, especially being aware of kinks in the neck/head position that can add tension. The goal is for the larynx (voice box) to be relaxed. Second, inhale keeping the shoulders / upper body relaxed, and feel a nice expansion of the rib cage in the back. Now - and I believe this is the essence of the Italian “appoggio” technique - maintain the expanded rib cage and non-collapsed posture as you sing. Perhaps what is happening physiologically is that although the diaphragm is a muscle for inhalation, it stays active (via keeping the ribcage expanded) to provide a counterbalance against forces for exhalation so that there is an even steady breath pressure. Here is a good video where the baritone singer is given a towel as a prop to help energize and maintain the expanded rib cage while he sings, I think this may explain better than my words. The full “clip” starts here:  However, if you would like to jump ahead about 5 minutes, you can start here, with the kinetics consultant explaining the mechanics of posture and “breathing” :  I think this is a really good and worthwhile video for just a few minutes of your time, so please take a look. Happy singing!

Great question. I had the same question a couple years back, so I took to the interwebs. Google led me to the article I linked below. Here’s a quick paraphrase: This is the most important thing to recognize: don’t try to use the air from your diaphragm—instead, the goal is to use the space created by it.As a resonator, the voice uses a large space to resonate more loudly and comfortably, so learning the right, relaxed way to use the breath in singing—and, to a lesser extent, speaking—will have great effects on how comfortably and “powerfully” you can sing.Here’s a practical point: Take a quick breath in, but don’t “hold” the breath. Instead, “maintain” the breath you should have the sensation as if you could keep inhaling, but that you aren’t choosing to do so. (If the back of your throat is holding in pressure, then you’re “holding”, not “maintaining”.)Try to hold this feeling for a couple seconds. If you’re doing it right, you should feel a nice burn a couple layers beneath your abs. Don’t hold this too long—it’ll strengthen over time.Once you can comfortably maintain the breath for a good half-minute, then try singing a nice up-and-down melody while maintaining the breath. Don’t force accuracy of notes—just notice the relaxed feeling.(A note: If I recall correctly, this is called the method of apoggio in classical vocal training.)This link isn’t my article, but it goes into more detail, and I have found that the principles and methods discussed help to increase understanding of how the voice uses the breath, as well as helping to improve this function. Check it out: Correct Breathing and 'Support' for Singing
